Go Weekly

15 Go Subtleties You May Not Already Know â€” A well written roundup of lesser-known Go features or idiosyncrasies thatâ€™s worth a skim even if only a few jump out at you. Or if you already know about them all, you can feel a warm glow for the rest of the day ğŸ˜ Topics include time.After, nil interfaces, and jsonâ€™s - tag.

Harrison Cramer

Get Oâ€™Reilly Book Data Engineering Design Patterns, Courtesy of Buf â€” Discover proven design patterns for building reliable, scalable data systems. This free Oâ€™Reilly ebook, courtesy of Buf, focuses on several important aspects of data engineering, including data ingestion, data quality, idempotency, andÂ more.

Buf sponsor

How Slow is Channel-Based Iteration? â€” The makers of the Go-powered Dolt database run an example involving iteration using two channel-based approaches, as well as iter.Pull. Conclusion? â€œThe haters are right: using channels for iteration isÂ slow.â€

Zach Musgrave

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.25.3 and 1.24.9 have been released. They're minor point releases which address a problem caused by an earlier security patch being overly restrictive when parsing X.509Â certificates.

  • The creator of the popular Lodash-like Lo library has started work on Ro, an attempt to bring the ReactiveX reactive programming model toÂ Go.

  • ğŸ§ It's been a long time since we linked to it, but if you'd also like to listen to Go news, the Cup o'Go podcast is still going out every week.

Gist of Go: Atomics â€” In Go, â€˜atomicsâ€™ are low-level synchronization primitives from sync/atomic for performing lock-free, thread-safe operations on shared memory values. Sometimes, race-free concurrency without a mutex really isÂ possible.

Anton Zhiyanov

A Modern Approach to Preventing CSRF/CORF in Go â€” Go 1.25 introduced a new http.CrossOriginProtection middleware that can help protect against cross-site and cross-origin forgery attacks using browser security headers instead ofÂ tokens.

Alex Edwards

Ebitengine

ã€

#â€‹573 â€” October 8, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

qjs: Run JavaScript in Go â€” A new Cgo-free runtime option to integrate JavaScript into Go apps. Rather than bind to a native library, it uses a fork of QuickJS compiled to WebAssembly and then run under Wazero. You get ES2023 compatibility, sandboxing, zero-copy sharing of values between Go and JS, and the ability to expose Go functions to JS and viceÂ versa.

Nguyen Ngoc Phuong and Contributors

Tuple - The Fastest Way to Review AI Slop â€” Wasting hours debugging AI code? Tuple brings your team together in seconds to figure it out, clean it up, andÂ ship.

Tuple sponsor

How Cloudflare Found a Bug in Go's arm64 Compiler â€” At the scale Cloudflare uses Go, small problems magnify quickly and rare problems will occur at frequency. Hereâ€™s what they discovered and how they fixed it. â€œThis was a very fun problem toÂ debug.â€

Thea Heinen (Cloudflare)

IN BRIEF:

  • Go v1.25.2 and v1.24.8 have been released with security fixes to a wide variety of packages.

  • ğŸ§ On the Go Podcast, Dominic St-Pierre talks about why, as a gopher, he's excited about Gleam, a relatively new Go-like language that runs on the Erlang VM.

  • ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· GopherCon Korea 2025 is taking place in a month's time, on NovemberÂ 9.

  • ğŸ’„ It appears that the Charm folks might be experimenting with porting their libraries to JavaScript?

How to Reproduce and Fix an I/O Data Race with Go and DTrace â€” The author ran into a weird test failure that only occurred in CI due to a data race involving the filesystem. Hereâ€™s how he reproduced it locally and worked around theÂ issue.

Philippe Gaultier

â–¶Â Â Reverse Engineering Doesn't Have to Be Hard â€” A fantastic introductory look at reverse engineering a piece of Go-powered malware. Itâ€™s not aimed at Go developers and no Go coding is involved, but if you havenâ€™t done any reverse engineering before, youâ€™ll pick up some essentialÂ techniques.

John Hammond

Grab a Copy of Data Engineering Design Patterns, Courtesy of Buf â€” Build resilient data pipelines with proven patterns. Covers idempotency, error handling, observability & more. DownloadÂ free.

Buf sponsor

ğŸ“º Terminating Elegantly: A Guide to Graceful Shutdowns â€“ A tight and useful talk focusing on Go apps running under Kubernetes. Alex Pliutau

ğŸ“º Building a Coding Agent in Go from Scratch Bill Kennedy

ğŸ¤–Â yzma: Perform Local Inference with VLMs andÂ LLMs â€” Use Go to perform local inference with Vision Language Models (VLMs) and Large Language Models (LLMs). It uses purego and ffi so calls can be made directly to llama.cpp withoutÂ CGo.

The Hybrid Group

Lo v1.52.0: A Lodash-Style Library for Go 1.18+ â€” Inspired by JavaScriptâ€™s Lodash, Lo brings similar utility methods to Go for working with slices, maps, and more. v1.52 introduces a variety of improvements and a new docs site. (The image on this release page is quiteÂ something..!)

Samuel Berthe

PG Back Web 0.5: A Postgres Backup System with Web Interface â€” A Go-powered app for bringing a bit more of a friendly user interface to Postgres backups, as well as scheduled backups, backup monitoring, and webhooks. Itâ€™s available as a Docker image and now supports Postgres 18Â too.

Luis Eduardo

  • Ginkgo 2.26 â€“ Mature testingÂ framework. v2.26 adds the ability to generate JSON-formatted reports compatible with go test'sÂ format.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹572 â€” October 1, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Flight Recorder in Go 1.25 â€” Billed as â€œa powerful new tool in the Go diagnostics toolboxâ€, the â€˜flight recorderâ€™ continuously collects execution traces and buffers the past few seconds, letting you capture exactly the window of time needed to diagnose a problem after itâ€™s alreadyÂ happened.

Carlos Amedee and Michael Knyszek

Cloud Infrastructure: Startup toÂ Scale â€” Deploy and scale apps with containers, Supabase, AWS, Terraform, and CI/CD pipelines. Go from startup speed to enterprise-grade reliability through the three phases of growth: Startup, Growth, andÂ Scale.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Accepted! Go Proposals Distilled â€” A new series of blog posts covering accepted Go language proposals â€” so you can get up to speed with things coming to future versions of Go without having to read the entire proposal. So far Anton has covered maphash.Hasher and new(expr).

Anton Zhiyanov

IN BRIEF:

  • The Traefik project celebrates its tenth anniversary with a look at how it's matured, grown, and become one of the best known Go-powered infrastructure tools.

  • JetBrains offers a preview of its new Islands theme coming to its IDEs, including GoLand â€“ you can try it now, however.

ğŸ“ŠÂ 'We Tried Go's Experimental Green Tea Garbage Collector and It Didn't Help Performance' â€” For Doltâ€™s use case (which is quite specific), the experimental â€˜Green Teaâ€™ garbage collector you can opt to use in Go 1.25 provided no real benefits, but your mileage may vary so itâ€™s worth tryingÂ out.

Zach Mushrave (Dolt)

Starving, Sleeping, and Yielding: Understanding Go's Scheduler â€” â€œWriting concurrent programs in Go is easy, but understanding the behaviour (or, more frequently, misbehaviour) of those programs is anotherÂ matter.â€

John Arundel

3 Critical TTL Patterns for In-Memory Caching â€” Leaning on the authorâ€™s own Hot library that provides fast in-memory caching for GoÂ apps.

Samuel Berthe

âš¡ Supercharge Postgres: 2PB Scale & 1.5t Metrics/Day â€” TigerData makes Postgres the fastest database for modern workloads: 2PB scale, 1.5T metrics/day, no blackÂ boxes.

TigerData sponsor

ğŸ“º OpenCV for Go and WebAssembly with Ron Evans â€“ A live 90-minute session about computer vision with Ron Evans (of TinyGo and GoCVÂ fame). OpenCV Live

ğŸ“„ The new() Function Will Take an Expression in GoÂ 1.26 Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Build a Water Simulation in Go with raylib-go Tim Little

ğŸ“„ Register Allocation in the Go Compiler Vladimir Makarov

ğŸ“„ Slice Tails Don't Grow Forever Ted Unangst

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Do 2.0: Type-Safe Dependency Injection Toolkit â€” A library that provides the dependency injection design pattern and uses generics instead of reflection in order to provide a type-safe API. If youâ€™re already a Do user, thereâ€™s a guide for upgrading from v1.x to v2.0 to follow. GitHubÂ repo.

Samuel Berthe

Failsafe: Fault Tolerance, Resilience Patterns & Policies â€” A library for building fault-tolerant apps where you can wrap code in various resilience policies such as Retry, CircuitBreaker, RateLimiter, Timeout, and Fallback. Releases in recent weeks add several new features including usage tracking (to enforce fairness) and execution budgets for setting a maximum â€˜budgetâ€™ for retries or hedges across aÂ system.

Jonathan Halterman

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ Tuple - how developers at Shopify, Figma, and Stripe collaborate on code. Stop dictating and take control withÂ Tuple.

PegoMock 4.3: A Powerful Yet Simple Mocking Framework â€” Brings an easy-to-read DSL to mocking. You can do stubbing and argument matching, asÂ well.

Peter GÃ¶tz

eBPF Web Fingerprint: Library and Server for TCP and TLSÂ Fingerprinting
Alberto Ventafridda

  • ğŸ©» dicom 1.1 â€“ DICOM medical image parsing library and CLIÂ tool.

  • Open Policy Agent (OPA) 1.9 â€“ General-purpose policy engine.

  • MCP-Go 0.41 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP) for integrating with AIÂ apps.

  • Fiber 3.0.0 RC2 â€“ Express.js-inspired Web framework forÂ Go.

  • Shiori 1.8 â€“ Simple bookmark manager app.

item.title: ã€The talks from GopherCon UK 2025 go liveã€‘GopherCon UK 2025 çš„æ¼”è®²ä¸Šçº¿
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹571 â€” September 24, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go's Support for Valgrind Instrumentation â€” Valgrind is a commonly used instrumentation framework for creating tools that can do profiling and detect various memory management and threading bugs in apps. This still-experimental support for Valgrind in Go opens up a wealth of extra opportunities for low-level diagnostics for GoÂ programs.

Roland Shoemaker

ğŸ’¡ This Hacker News discussion has more details, including a comment from the author of the pull request/CL about what the support was initially intendedÂ for.

Go Event-Driven: From the Watermill Creators â€” MiÅ‚osz and Robert from Three Dots Labs are launching the next edition of their hands-on training. It teaches the tricky parts of event-driven systems such as the outbox pattern, message ordering, and sagas. Don't sleep on this one. Opens autumnÂ 2025.

Three Dots Labs sponsor

â–¶Â Â Twenty Talks from GopherCon UK 2025 â€” A YouTube playlist containing the just-uploaded talks from last monthâ€™s London-based Go conference. Every talk is technical and deep, but you might particularly enjoy Daniel Martiâ€™s Whatâ€™s Coming in Go 1.25, Roland Shoemaker talking about Go security, or Emily Achieng talking about Go module hygiene and keeping your go.sum and go.mod files inÂ check.

GopherCon UK

Practical Networking Patterns in Go â€” A new section of the on-going â€œGo Optimization Guideâ€ featuring 13 guides to the various topics involved in building scalable, networked Go apps â€” including benchmarking, how to achieve â€˜massive concurrencyâ€™, diagnostics, transport protocols, low-level tuning, andÂ more.

Alexander Stavonin

IN BRIEF:

  • The latest Go developer survey is open for just one more week, closing next Tuesday, September 30. You can take it here.

  • WebAssembly/WASM is an increasingly common compilation target for Go, so it's neat to see the WebAssembly 3.0 standard is now 'live' (and already ships with most browsers) with various features that should improve interoperability in the long-term, including garbage collection, tail calls, and exception handling.

  • The IEEE has published a list of the top 'programming languages' in 2025 with Go coming in at numberÂ 10.

Building Conwayâ€™s Game of Life with raylib-go â€” Just a bit of fun. Hereâ€™s the resultingÂ code.

Tim Little

Kubernetes CPU Limits and Go â€” An update of an article from 2024. Goâ€™s runtime doesnâ€™t inherently know that itâ€™s running within a Kubernetes environment, so there are tweaks you can make. However, also bear in mind Go 1.25â€™s changes to GOMAXPROCSâ€™sÂ defaults.

William Kennedy

ğŸ“„ How Fast is Go? Simulating Millions of Particles on a Smart TV â€“ â€œGo is able to simulate 2.5 million particles at 60 fps while sending data at 30 fps to in theory over 300 clients, maybe even aÂ thousand.â€ David Gerrells

ğŸ“„ Making a Cross-Platform Game using Pion and WebRTC Datachannels â€“ The current setup has some drawbacks, but thereâ€™s a lot of potential here if you want to exploreÂ it. Srayan Jana

ğŸ“„ CSRF Protection via Headers in Go 1.25 Jon Calhoun

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

ğŸ¤–Â GoMLX: An Accelerated Machine Learning Framework for Go â€” A set of machine learning libraries and tools designed to act as a sort-of Go alternative to PyTorch or TensorFlow. Despite the name, itâ€™s not related to Appleâ€™s MLX framework and is actually Linux-only for now. It does, however, open up the opportunity to train and use ML models directly from Go, as Eli Bendersky explains in this introductoryÂ post.

GoMLX Team

TableWriter 1.1: Render Rich Text-Based Tables â€” A flexible library for rendering tabular data to ASCII, Unicode, Markdown, HTML, or for colorized terminals. The README is packed withÂ examples.

Oleku Konko

Secure Your Agentic Apps with Auth for GenAI â€” Secure your agentic apps with features like User Authentication for AI agents, Token Vault, and more with Auth0â€™s Auth for GenAI (exclusively in DeveloperÂ Preview).

Auth0 sponsor

Gojekyll: A Fast Go Implementation of Jekyll â€” Jekyll is a very popular Ruby-powered static site generator â€“ this is a â€˜partially-compatibleâ€™ clone that boasts enhanced performance and portability by being written inÂ Go. Worth a look if you have a Jekyll-powered site but want to remove Ruby from yourÂ stack.

Oliver Steele and Daniil Gentili

Valgo 0.7: An Expressive Validator Library â€” Type-safe and extensible validator library built upon generics. Rules are written in functions and not in struct tags. v0.7 adds new validation helpers and type-safe validators that remove codegen and width-specificÂ types.
